questions.prompt: A group G is cyclic if:
options: G = ⟨a⟩ for some element a in G
questions.explanation: A group is cyclic if it can be generated by a single element, meaning every element can be written as aⁿ for some integer n.

questions.prompt: Which of the following groups is NOT cyclic?
options: The Klein 4-group V₄ = {e, a, b, ab} where a² = b² = (ab)² = e
⟨i⟩ in the complex numbers under multiplication
questions.explanation: The Klein 4-group is not cyclic. All non-identity elements have order 2, so no single element can generate the entire group. Z₆, Z, and ⟨i⟩ are all cyclic.

questions.prompt: In Z₁₂, how many generators are there?
questions.explanation: The generators of Zₙ are the elements k where gcd(k,n) = 1. For Z₁₂, these are 1, 5, 7, 11, giving φ(12) = 4 generators.

questions.prompt: If G is a cyclic group of order n generated by a, what is the order of aᵏ?
questions.explanation: In a cyclic group of order n generated by a, the order of aᵏ is n/gcd(k,n).
All cyclic groups are abelian. If G = ⟨a⟩, then any two elements aᵐ and aⁿ satisfy aᵐaⁿ = aᵐ⁺ⁿ = aⁿ⁺ᵐ = aⁿaᵐ.

questions.prompt: Every subgroup of a cyclic group is:
questions.explanation: Every subgroup of a cyclic group is cyclic. This is the Fundamental Theorem of Cyclic Groups.

questions.prompt: If G is a cyclic group of order n, how many subgroups does G have?
options: φ(n) subgroups, where φ is Euler's totient function
One subgroup for each divisor of n
questions.explanation: A cyclic group of order n has exactly one subgroup of order d for each divisor d of n, including d=1 and d=n.

questions.prompt: Which of the following correctly classifies all finite cyclic groups?
options: All finite cyclic groups of the same order are isomorphic
No two cyclic groups are isomorphic
Only cyclic groups of prime order are isomorphic
Cyclic groups are never isomorphic to each other
questions.explanation: The Fundamental Theorem states that any cyclic group of order n is isomorphic to Zₙ, so all cyclic groups of the same order are isomorphic to each other.

questions.prompt: The only infinite cyclic group (up to isomorphism) is:
questions.explanation: Every infinite cyclic group is isomorphic to (Z, +). This is the unique infinite cyclic group up to isomorphism.

questions.prompt: In Z₂₀, what is the unique subgroup of order 4?
questions.explanation: In Z₂₀, the unique subgroup of order 4 is generated by 20/4 = 5, giving ⟨5⟩ = {0, 5, 10, 15}.

title: Cyclic Groups - Direct Products and Applications

questions.prompt: The direct product Z₂ × Z₃ is isomorphic to:
questions.explanation: Since gcd(2,3) = 1, by the Chinese Remainder Theorem, Z₂ × Z₃ ≅ Z₆. The direct product of cyclic groups of coprime orders is cyclic.

options: Yes, it is isomorphic to Z₂₄
Yes, because all direct products are cyclic
No, because one of the factors is not prime order
questions.explanation: Z₄ × Z₆ is not cyclic because gcd(4,6) = 2 ≠ 1. Instead, Z₄ × Z₆ ≅ Z₂ × Z₁₂.

questions.prompt: What is the order of the element (1, 1) in Z₄ × Z₆?
questions.explanation: The order of (a,b) in Zₘ × Zₙ is lcm(|a|, |b|). In Z₄, |1| = 4 since 1 generates all of Z₄. In Z₆, |1| = 6 since 1 generates all of Z₆. Therefore |(1,1)| = lcm(4,6) = 12.

questions.prompt: How many elements of order 2 are there in Z₂ × Z₂?
questions.explanation: Z₂ × Z₂ = {(0,0), (0,1), (1,0), (1,1)}. The elements of order 2 are those where 2·element = (0,0) but element ≠ (0,0). These are (0,1), (1,0), and (1,1), giving 3 elements of order 2.

questions.prompt: The group U(20) of units modulo 20 has order:
questions.explanation: U(20) consists of elements coprime to 20. Using Euler's totient: φ(20) = φ(4·5) = φ(4)φ(5) = 2·4 = 8.
